source: Public blog-style content inspired by Medium, Dev.to, FreeCodeCamp, and LinkedIn Creator posts

level_1: One of my seniors said, 'Your GitHub is your new resume'. I didn't get it then — but I do now.
A blog I read said, 'LinkedIn is where people notice you. GitHub is where people trust you.'
Even if you're a beginner, just start with what you’ve learned — and write it cleanly.
I used to think profiles were only for job-seekers. Turns out, it's for anyone who wants to be seen.
Your brand is built by what you post, share, and build — one step at a time.
level_2: I updated my LinkedIn summary with my goals — and got 3 networking DMs the next day.
My GitHub had 10+ small projects, but none explained well. A blog post taught me to rewrite my READMEs.
After adding a photo and links to my profile, recruiters started viewing my page more.
A mentor once told me — 'Pin what you're proud of, not what you practiced.' That helped!
Consistency > perfection — just keep updating and showing your growth.
level_3: One blog suggested writing a 'You in 1 sentence' headline. Mine: 'AI-curious student learning in public'.
Developers say your GitHub README is like your portfolio homepage — treat it seriously.
I started posting monthly project summaries — and got featured in a LinkedIn newsletter.
Your personal brand grows when people see you adding value — not just flexing skills.
Bloggers recommend using tools like shields.io for visual branding in repos.
level_4: I got a freelance offer via LinkedIn just because someone followed my tech posts.
One Dev.to blogger wrote: 'Your GitHub should feel like a library, not a scrapyard.'
I created a project walkthrough thread on Twitter and LinkedIn — 3k views in a week.
My pinned repo helped me land a speaker invite at a student conference.
Building in public builds trust — and trust brings opportunities.

level_1: Don’t leave your profile blank — fill at least name, photo, and about.
level_2: Avoid over-sharing or bragging — let projects speak.
Don’t post only achievements — share learnings too.
level_3: Don’t mix too many roles — it weakens your brand clarity.
Avoid too frequent edits — focus on long-term vision.
level_4: Consistency builds trust — randomness confuses.
Don’t fake it — your brand should reflect your real self.
